It is good. So good that I even got all the achievements for it. Not going to play the New Game+, but that's because I am more into narrative and exploration part of the game, and they are all covered now. Or most of them, at least. But I now know that I will be getting the sequel, for sure.

First thing that I've noticed was how insanely good it looks with HDR on QD-OLED. It's been almost a year now since I had ASUS PG32UCDM, and this is the first game, where enabling HDR truly changes the experience. In previous games, even in those where there was a specific HDR toggle, it either did not do much for the picture at all or even made it worse. GYLT became very washed out, AC Mirage made night look like it's day... Dead Island 2 seemed to make scenes have more details, at least, but can't say if it mattered that much overall, since I completed the game shortly before I got the monitor, so just used it for a quick and dirty test of HDR, nothing else.

In GoW it makes a lot of difference. Not like you can't play in SDR or anything, but when I took a short break and my monitor semi-turned off due to proximity sensor, which semi-disabled HDR, I noticed that because something felt wrong, like everything is almost gray (not the washed-out effect, it looked different). Early in the game there is a scene where a candle-light is shown very close to the screen, and it felt almost real. Highlights on armor and weapons (and generally on metal things) also look amazing when HDR is enabled.

Until you get to some scene, where textures won't load right away. Yup, that happens, and relatively often, even though my PC is quite powerful, I have 24Gbs of VRAM, 64Gbs of RAM and 990Pro for SSD, so no reason for them not to load, but it was happening periodically. Often times, it as something small, but sometimes bigger objects also did not load properly. Including the World Serpent, which looked very bad. I also did not notice any pattern for this behavior.

Speaking of the Serpent: the sense of scale is great here. Seeing the Serpent for the first time is practically jaw-dropping. The fact that you can see it from a lot of places on the map also adds to this feeling of... "Smallness of oneself". But it's not just the Serpent. There are dragons, albeit just a few of them, and there was at least 1 giant. But even more common ogres and trolls feel imposing. Not like that affects combat system, but it does help somewhat with the narrative and overall feel of the environment.

The combat itself, though, is not to my liking. I think biggest issue for me is the camera placement. Yes, it makes fights more personal, but forces you to rely on those small arrows to know where enemies at your back are. Arrows that were very difficult to see in some lighting, because they were just blending with it. Having no way to quickly turn and switch between enemies (besides the quick-turn button) did not help me much.

Another part was the use of axe. This is just personal preference, I guess, I am more partial to swords. Or maybe it's more about how slow and heavy it felt. Slower and heavier than combat in Batman Arkham series. And it makes total sense to be that way, and hitting with the axe can feel quite satisfying, too, it's just I am more used to DMC-like combat which both gives you a little bit of extra range, ability to see more stuff around you and react better to situations. It's more... Fluid, I guess. Blades, which get unlocked later in the game, were better, but they felt almost like a long-distance weapon (which again made sense), so less personal. They did feel very good when dealing with large numbers of enemies at the same time, though.

There is another problem with the combat for me and it's that it felt quite repetitive for me. You do have some "tools", that can add variety, but to me they felt almost situational. There are also not that many combos. I was mostly tapping "X", sometimes using "Y" (mostly for cleave attack, really), waiting for the runic attacks to get off cooldown, and periodically using arrows. Oh, and dodge and parry, of course. It is possible, that I am just a noob, though.

I would also prefer more diversity with finishers. It looked to me like every enemy had only 1 finisher, and it did not matter whether I was using a weapon (and which weapon exactly) or not. So while they feel good, they became stale at some point. Boss fights also were not that interesting in terms of mechanics. There were challenging fights, don't get me wrong, but I think only fight against a dragon, where you had to throw stuff at him was somewhat unique (although reminiscent of fights with Ancients), while the rest were more about how frequently some attacks are thrown at you that you need to dodge/parry, and amount of damage you receive, if you get hit. But, at least, you can summon a squirrel.

But I think this game is not so much about the combat, as it's about exploration and narrative. Which can't really be separated here, and that's a good thing. Level design and thus environmental story-telling is amazing here. I also liked it, that it did not went as far with "open-world": it is "open", yes, but the number of diversions is limited, and you can complete most of them while moving towards the main goal (or side quest goal) without much of backtracking. You will need to backtrack to collect everything, of course, but to me it did not feel like a pain, at all.

One of the reasons for that was banter, which is part of the narrative, as well. This was one of the complaints I had about Banishers(which clearly was inspired by GoW), where travelling from place to place was almost always silent, even though you had 2 characters. In GoW it's not the case. Atreus talks, Kratos responds. Mimir... Talks a lot. Yes, a lot of those talks happen when you are on boat, and less so when you revisiting the same location (although some places¬†can have extra dialogues, if you return to them later in the game), but they are timed quite nicely, so that I rarely got bored traveling from place to place, and when I did get bored, it was closer to the end of the playthrough, probably because the set of dialogues has depleted.

Anyway, those dialogues are not just a "nice to have". They also tell you more about the world (and Norse mythology), as well as show father and son bonding. Which is, obviously one of the main themes of the game. And, let me tell you... Even though Kratos is far-far-far from perfect, there were times, when I caught myself thinking, that I would have preferred him to my own father. Note, that I have not played previous games (since PC gamer), and I now would like to know what brought him to this point, how was he before. Regardless of that, there was clear care for his son, and we can see how he grows through-out the game. Those banter dialogues expand somewhat on that growth as well.

Narrative is not always perfect here, of course. Earlier in the game, for example, they decide to randomly hunt a boar, despite the idea of heading directly to the mountain. Some of the side-quests are essentially courier quests with maybe a new location to explore. Although there are some that do show a bit more bonding of Kratos and Atreus, at least through sharing some feelings.

But then there are seemingly little things, that just... Work. Like how you get your "compass" in UI, and how it makes sense from internal lore perspective. Or how the main story ends not with a fight, but essentially with walking and more banter (and a few cutscenes, of course). As if it's not really an action game (with some RPG elements, which are fine, they seemed to connect with everything else nicely), but a story-driven game. It made the ending feel more personal, and thus more satisfying.

So, yes, I can recommend this game, for sure. It is a good one, and it's been awhile since I was this satisfied with a game. I'd probably even give it 9/10.

To start out, if you're expecting the same experience as earlier games in the GOW franchise, skip this.

I went into God of war 2018 expecting improvements and innovations the built upon the original gameplay loop found in earlier GOW titles. Instead, I found a heap of mechanics that don't feel like they should be in the series at all, and don't even work in conjunction with one another to create a satisfying, or even remotely coherent experience. The best way to describe this would be that GOW 2018 is a ham-fisted attempt at rebooting the series with little regard for what made the original games work so well.

GOW 2018 can effectively be split into four segments; Combat, Puzzle Solving, RPG advancement, and Storytelling.

-COMBAT- 5/10

The combat in GOW 2018 is - for lack of a better term - outrageously sluggish and unsatisfying. Between the absurdly repetitive combos, awfully balanced Runic abilities, disgusting choice of camera angle, flat sound design, and lack of enemy variety, I found myself dreading the next encounter even more than I dreaded the next 'puzzle' that the game had to offer. As of writing this review, I have made it through half of the game, and the combat has officially broken my will to continue any further.

In a game where I would expect my attack chains to feel impactful, chaining attacks against enemies is boring. Your optimal approach against most enemy encounters is a mixture of hit-and-run, and spamming runic spells, all of which feel nearly identical with the exception of range alterations as you progress through the game. 

The 'spellcasting' in this game is another can of worms entirely. Not only does it not synergize with the existing attack chains offered by either of your weapons (All two of them) spellcasting seems to trivialize encounters. All of the runic spells feel like they were added to the game after-the-fact with little regard for how they would actually interact with your innate weapon skills.

Last on combat is Atreus, and the bow. This feels like yet another mechanic slapped onto the game for no particular reason, other than to fulfill the need for puzzle variety. There's no depth to his arrow or summon selection, and you'll mostly default to spamming square since there was no thought put into the timing of his attacks in conjunction with your own. I feel like I don't need to explain why mashing Square is irritating. At some point, I just stopped using him altogether.

-PUZZLES- 4/10

Puzzles in GOW are what you would expect from the GOW genre. Move thing there, press button here, etc. For the most part, they are annoying, and in the way of progress. If the game was fast paced, this wouldn't be as much of a problem, but with combat encounters already being sluggish, every slowdown between them was a motivation killer for me.

Occasionally, you'll come across a well-crafted puzzle that - while not difficult in the slightest - does serve to give you a little break from the monotonous tone of the entire game.

Overall though, I'd say they were a huge waste of time.

-RPG ADVANCEMENT- 2/10

I'd say that the crafting, gear, and general overall stat-block of GOW 2018 is a joke, and may be the most unnecessary addition to this franchise. 

With the puzzles in this game already being a gigantic slog, I was at no point motivated to actually go out of my way to find gear. Despite this though, I had accumulated over 30 pieces of useless equipment by the half-way point of the game, 90% of which I would never even consider wearing. Build variety is largely unimportant in the game, save for the occasional "Equip this to take less damage from X" gear that I refused to use.

There's not much to say on the gear in GOW 2018, other than it's a pointless, ultimately annoying addition that you can effectively ignore as long as you're decent at Dodging/blocking. However, by ignoring the RPG elements of the game, you're punished with spongey encounters, forcing you to indulge in this nonsense in order to shorten the sluggish combat as much as possible.

Skill leveling for each of the weapon is - likewise - uninteresting and largely pointless. At no point did I feel like I needed to use anything other than the Leviathan Axe's improved 4 hit combo, or the improved combo for the blades of chaos. The combat encounters are not designed in such a way that the improvements for either weapon tree are actually meaningful at all, making them feel out of place, and slapped on for the sake of padding the already atrocious RPG elements in the game.

Add on that the menus are ugly, obtuse, and a pain in the ass to navigate considering the bloat of item types in the game, and you've got an utter shitshow.

~STORY~ 6.5/10

I'll give it to this game, humanizing Kratos was the right direction for the franchise to take.

Unfortunately, besides that, the story telling in GOW 2018 is just alright. While most of the VA's give an outstanding performance, the game's script is exceptionally mid, at best, and it is consistently bogged down by the irritatingly slow pacing of the gameplay, and everyone's least favorite trend with modern games - Dialogue bloat.

Atreus, for one, never shuts the hell up. Not only does this child yap constantly throughout the game, but his dialogue is extremely stilted, his lines are inconsistent, and his characterization is so ham-fisted that I felt like I was listening to a damn Sunday morning Cartoon, and not a dark-and-gritty reimagining of God-of-War. Atreus as a character is so tonally deaf, that I was about to mute his dialogue at several points throughout the game just to get a break from his incessant chatter. Unfortunately, I made the uninformed decision that he might say something interesting while roaming the overworld. 

He never does.

The game's focus is the dynamic between Kratos and his son. While I feel that there are moments that shine above the rest and capture sparkles of incredible storytelling, they are layered between hours of what I can only call melodramatic, hollywood nonsense. Atreus is unrealistically stupid, Kratos is absurdly unreasonable, and many of the conflicts between the two feel so manufactured that it hurts to listen to.

As with most AAA games, you should not go into this expecting an exceptional story.

Overall, this game was an incredible disappointment. At its worst, it is slow, uninteresting, and frustrating, and at it's best, it's a passable story about a father and his son on a journey through Norse Disneyland.

To start out, if you're expecting the same experience as earlier games in the GOW franchise, skip this.

I went into God of war 2018 expecting improvements and innovations the built upon the original gameplay loop found in earlier GOW titles. Instead, I found a heap of mechanics that don't feel like they should be in the series at all, and don't even work in conjunction with one another to create a satisfying, or even remotely coherent experience. The best way to describe this would be that GOW 2018 is a ham-fisted attempt at rebooting the series with little regard for what made the original games work so well.

GOW 2018 can effectively be split into four segments; Combat, Puzzle Solving, RPG advancement, and Storytelling.

-COMBAT- 5/10

The combat in GOW 2018 is - for lack of a better term - outrageously sluggish and unsatisfying. Between the absurdly repetitive combos, awfully balanced Runic abilities, disgusting choice of camera angle, flat sound design, and lack of enemy variety, I found myself dreading the next encounter even more than I dreaded the next 'puzzle' that the game had to offer. As of writing this review, I have made it through half of the game, and the combat has officially broken my will to continue any further.

In a game where I would expect my attack chains to feel impactful, chaining attacks against enemies is boring. Your optimal approach against most enemy encounters is a mixture of hit-and-run, and spamming runic spells, all of which feel nearly identical with the exception of range alterations as you progress through the game. 

The 'spellcasting' in this game is another can of worms entirely. Not only does it not synergize with the existing attack chains offered by either of your weapons (All two of them) spellcasting seems to trivialize encounters. All of the runic spells feel like they were added to the game after-the-fact with little regard for how they would actually interact with your innate weapon skills.

Last on combat is Atreus, and the bow. This feels like yet another mechanic slapped onto the game for no particular reason, other than to fulfill the need for puzzle variety. There's no depth to his arrow or summon selection, and you'll mostly default to spamming square since there was no thought put into the timing of his attacks in conjunction with your own. I feel like I don't need to explain why mashing Square is irritating. At some point, I just stopped using him altogether.

-PUZZLES- 4/10

Puzzles in GOW are what you would expect from the GOW genre. Move thing there, press button here, etc. For the most part, they are annoying, and in the way of progress. If the game was fast paced, this wouldn't be as much of a problem, but with combat encounters already being sluggish, every slowdown between them was a motivation killer for me.

Occasionally, you'll come across a well-crafted puzzle that - while not difficult in the slightest - does serve to give you a little break from the monotonous tone of the entire game.

Overall though, I'd say they were a huge waste of time.

-RPG ADVANCEMENT- 2/10

I'd say that the crafting, gear, and general overall stat-block of GOW 2018 is a joke, and may be the most unnecessary addition to this franchise. 

With the puzzles in this game already being a gigantic slog, I was at no point motivated to actually go out of my way to find gear. Despite this though, I had accumulated over 30 pieces of useless equipment by the half-way point of the game, 90% of which I would never even consider wearing. Build variety is largely unimportant in the game, save for the occasional "Equip this to take less damage from X" gear that I refused to use.

There's not much to say on the gear in GOW 2018, other than it's a pointless, ultimately annoying addition that you can effectively ignore as long as you're decent at Dodging/blocking. However, by ignoring the RPG elements of the game, you're punished with spongey encounters, forcing you to indulge in this nonsense in order to shorten the sluggish combat as much as possible.

Skill leveling for each of the weapon is - likewise - uninteresting and largely pointless. At no point did I feel like I needed to use anything other than the Leviathan Axe's improved 4 hit combo, or the improved combo for the blades of chaos. The combat encounters are not designed in such a way that the improvements for either weapon tree are actually meaningful at all, making them feel out of place, and slapped on for the sake of padding the already atrocious RPG elements in the game.

Add on that the menus are ugly, obtuse, and a pain in the ass to navigate considering the bloat of item types in the game, and you've got an utter shitshow.

~STORY~ 6.5/10

I'll give it to this game, humanizing Kratos was the right direction for the franchise to take.

Unfortunately, besides that, the story telling in GOW 2018 is just alright. While most of the VA's give an outstanding performance, the game's script is exceptionally mid, at best, and it is consistently bogged down by the irritatingly slow pacing of the gameplay, and everyone's least favorite trend with modern games - Dialogue bloat.

Atreus, for one, never shuts the hell up. Not only does this child yap constantly throughout the game, but his dialogue is extremely stilted, his lines are inconsistent, and his characterization is so ham-fisted that I felt like I was listening to a damn Sunday morning Cartoon, and not a dark-and-gritty reimagining of God-of-War. Atreus as a character is so tonally deaf, that I was about to mute his dialogue at several points throughout the game just to get a break from his incessant chatter. He never does.

The game's focus is the dynamic between Kratos and his son. While I feel that there are moments that shine above the rest and capture sparkles of incredible storytelling, they are layered between hours of what I can only call melodramatic, hollywood nonsense. As with most AAA games, you should not go into this expecting an exceptional story.
